threats.title: Developer commits secret to Git repo
threats.description: Developer commits secret to version control, intentionally or accidentally. While some protections for secret leakage may be active on pre or post commit stages its possible that the secret could be encoded (such as with a simple cypher or base64) or simply not detected. Anyone with read access to the repo can use those secrets to steal user data, hijack cloud services, upload malware to an image repo, etc. depending on the type of secret leaked.
threats.mitigation:
Ensure that secrets only have the permissions required to complete their tasks and have suitable source/destination restrictions (i.e mysql user with restricted/non% hostname and specific database permissions).


Ensure that secret management is in place to detect leaked secrets and automatically void leaked secrets, and routinely rotate secrets. Use or develop a system to log and monitor for abnormal secret usage such as secrets being used from non-production ip addresses, attempting to access data a secret doesnt have permission to access and shouldn't attempt to access in normal operation, etc.

Ensure that only those who need access to secrets have access to the needed secrets, and that permission to view secrets isn't freely given. add special code revision and code analysis for any code that handles secrets and injectable/substitution strings together (i.e pipeline-ci.yml, sql queries, rest api queries).

Ensure that the repo is only accessable in a protected environment such as a vpn or a private repository, for open source/source available projects a second private cloned repo could be used for development while the public repo is available after carefully reviewed code is pulled in

threats.title: New STRIDE threat
threats.description: Provide a description for this threat
threats.mitigation: Provide remediation for this threat or a reason if status is N/A

threats.title: User bypasses security gate
threats.description: A new teammember is annoyed that a detected vulnerability blocking the build of an automatic build and disables the security gate, the security gate remains disabled for some time and bad code eventually makes it to production.
threats.mitigation:
Ensure that logging is in place to detect the state of the security gate (success, fails, fails to trigger at all, etc) and submit this data to all key team members and/or management.

Disallow modifications to the pipeline without multiple senior teammember oversight, ensuring that multiple authorized persons sign off on changes to the pipeline.

Using different repo's for testing and production code, with the production repo only being modifiable by senior teammembers, and the production repo being held to higher standards than testing environments can be done, but isn't recommended due to shifting security  towards production (to the right).

threats.title: Attacker taints dependant package with malicious code
threats.description: A 3rd party package dependency  is hijacked by an attacker who then adds malicious code (such as a backdoor, cryptominer, or user data collection) and publishes the dependency.
threats.mitigation:
Ensure that only known safe and verified builds of dependencies are used. Using a local cache and/or keeping a store of known safe and verified hashes and file sizes can be used.

Perform automatic scanning of dependencies using a tool like anchore grype

threats.title: Attacker injects malware into repo
threats.description: An attacker uses a compromised users login to add malware to a repo.
threats.mitigation:
Audit login ip addresses and search for abnormal activity (unscheduled use of, or multiple logins from international or distant ip addresses, ip's outside of companies network/vpn, etc.) and flag or block changes made until the identity can be verified.

require periodic 2-factor authentication when making changes outside of a safe network.

Use development branches and require reviewing of all code before pushing to a master branch.

threats.title: Dast, Sast, sbom reports visible publicly
threats.description: Detailed analysis reports with specific information on detected vulnerabilities are publicly visible and available, an attacker uses these reports to help them find exploits in the codebase from where they can attack.
threats.mitigation:
Block access to the intermediate build artifacts or store them on a separate private service so that only authorised services and people can access these files.

Encrypt these files with an encryption and decryption key stored in the secrets vault.

Use a tool or service that accepts reports in a secure way,  and processes them into a form that isnt useful for an attacker (like a summary without specifics (i.e 5 critical issues, 3 warnings, 12 cautions)
